sample.title: Why Japan‚Äôs Economy Is at a Tipping Point
sample.description:
For 30 years, Japan‚Äôs prices were largely at a standstill. Now, a weak yen is changing everything. Here‚Äôs how consumers and businesses are coping with rising costs, and what it means for the nation‚Äôs economic future.

sample.title: Meta‚Äôs $2 Billion Bet To Win Over Enterprise Customers
sample.description:
In its latest aggressive AI move, Meta has acquired the intelligent agent firm Manus for $2 billion. The deal underscores Meta‚Äôs pursuit of enterprise dominance as the company faces mounting pressure to justify its massive AI infrastructure costs. However, the acquisition has sparked immediate backlash, with long-time Manus users retreating from the platform following the announcement. CNBC‚Äôs Julia Boorstin explores the high-stakes implications for Mark Zuckerberg as he warns investors that 2026 will see a significant surge in capital expenditures.

Produced and Edited by: Andrew Evers
Reporting by: Julia Boorstin, Stephen Desaulniers
Senior Director of Video: Jeniece Pettitt
Animation: Emily Park
Additional Footage: Getty Images

sample.title: Why Tariff Refunds Might Not Lower Prices
sample.description:
If the Supreme Court rules the tariffs are illegal, the refund process could become a lengthy back-and-forth between courts. Meanwhile, consumers are unlikely to see price drops as businesses deal with cash flow crunches. CNBC's Lori Ann LaRocco breaks down the three likeliest scenarios and why businesses will still be left waiting for their money.

Produced, Shot and Edited by: Charlotte Morabito
Reporting by: Lori Ann LaRocco
Animation: Jason Reginato, Emily Park

sample.title: How Anthropic quietly took on OpenAI
sample.description:
Daniela and Dario Amodei left OpenAI five years ago to form Anthropic.

Anthropic‚Äôs revenue has grown 10x annually for three straight years, with 85% coming from business customers ‚Äî the inverse of OpenAI‚Äôs consumer-heavy model.

sample.title: Why Automakers Want To Power AI Data Centers
sample.description:
With EV sales faltering and forecasts lowered, automakers are looking for ways to sell the batteries they are making. CNBC's Robert Ferris breaks down how and why automakers including General Motors and Ford are investing in a new industry.

Producer: Robert Ferris
Editor: Natalie Rice
Animation: Jason Reginato

sample.title: Who could replace Jamie Dimon as CEO of JPM?
sample.description:
JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon has for years maintained that his retirement was perpetually 5 years away. In 2024, for the first time, he acknowledged that window was shrinking.

That makes the inevitable questions surrounding Dimon‚Äôs tenure loom large as he approaches 70 years of age. Will JPMorgan‚Äôs era of dominance be over when Dimon exits as CEO?

sample.title: Being at your lowest is liberating, says Sophie Turner. #SophieTurner #Steal #BBCNews
Harry says Mail publisher made his wife Meghan's 'life a misery' | BBC News
sample.description:
The Duke of Sussex was visibly emotional as he told a court the life of his wife, the Duchess of Sussex, had been made "an absolute misery" by the publisher of the Daily Mail and the Mail on Sunday.

Prince Harry was speaking as he concluded his evidence in his case against Associated Newspapers Limited (ANL) at the High Court, much of which focused on articles about his relationships before meeting Meghan.

The prince's voice broke as he said the court battle had been a "horrible experience" for his family and that all he wanted was "an apology and some accountability".

He is one of seven high-profile claimants accusing ANL of "grave breaches of privacy" over a 20-year period. The publisher has denied wrongdoing.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#PrinceHarry #BBCNews

sample.title: Trump wants 'immediate negotiations' for Greenland but 'won't use force' | BBC News
sample.description:
US President Donald Trump says he is seeking immediate negotiations to acquire Greenland, which he called a "vast, almost uninhabited and undeveloped country, sitting undefended".

He told world leaders at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland: "We probably won't get anything unless I decide to use excessive strength and force, where we would be frankly unstoppable. But I won't do that"

The US already has more than 100 military personnel permanently stationed at its Pituffik base in Greenland's north-west - a facility it has operated since World War Two. 

Under existing agreements with Denmark, the US has the power to bring as many troops as it wants to Greenland.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Trump #Greenland #BBCNews
